01.text: This is the beginning of a new part of the story that runs through [[:en:bible:notes:mat:25:44|25:46]], where Jesus teaches about salvation and the final judgment. Here he begins to warn the people about the scribes and Pharisees.

Here "seat" represents the authority to rule and make judgments. AT: "have authority as Moses had" or "have authority to say what the law of Moses means" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

04.ref: they bind heavy burdens that are difficult to carry, and then they put them on people's shoulders
04.text: Here "burdens" are the many rules that the religious leaders create. AT: "they make you obey many rules that are difficult to follow" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

04.ref: they themselves will not move a finger
04.text: Here "move a finger" is a metaphor for giving help. AT: "they will not give the least amount of help" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

04.ref: They do all their deeds to be seen by people
04.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "They do all their deeds so that people can see what they do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

04.ref: For they make their phylacteries wide, and they enlarge the edges of their garments
04.text: Both of these are things the Pharisees do to appear as if they honor God more than other people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
small leather boxes containing paper with scripture written on it

04.ref: they enlarge the edges of their garments
04.text: Pharisees put long tassels on the bottom of their robes to show their devotion to God.

06.text: Jesus continues speaking to the crowds and disciples about the Pharisees.
Both of these are the places where the most important people sit.
large, open-air areas where people buy and sell items
This can be stated in active form. AT: "for people to call them 'Rabbi'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

08.ref: But you must not be called
08.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "But you must not let anyone call you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
All occurrences of "you" are plural and refer to all of Jesus' followers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

08.ref: call no man on earth your father
08.text: "do not call any man on earth your father" or "do not say that any man on earth is your father"
"Father" is an important title for God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "Also, do not let anyone call you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

08.ref: you have only one teacher, the Christ
08.text: When Jesus said "the Christ," he was speaking about himself in the third person. AT: "I, the Christ, am your only teacher" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

11.ref: he who is greatest among you
11.text: "the person who is most important among you"
Here "you" is plural and refers to Jesus' followers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "God will humble" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "God will make important" or "God will honor" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

13.text: Jesus begins to rebuke the religious leaders because of their hypocrisy.
"How terrible it will be for you!" See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:11:20|11:21]].

13.ref: You shut the kingdom of heaven against people
13.text: Here "kingdom of heaven" refers to God's rule as king. This phrase is found only in the book of Matthew. If possible, keep "heaven" in your translation. AT: "You prevent people from accepting our God in heaven as their king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"you do not accept God as your king"

13.ref: neither do you allow those about to enter to do so
13.text: "neither do you allow those who want to accept God as their king to do so"

13.ref: you go over sea and land
13.text: This is an idiom that means they go to distant places. AT: "you travel great distances" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"to make one person accept your religion"
Here "son of" is an idiom that means "one belonging to." AT: "person who belongs in hell" or "person who should go to hell" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
In the footnote, "devour" is an idiom that means to take by force. AT: "steal everything from women who have no men to protect them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

16.text: The Jewish leaders were spiritually blind. Although they thought of themselves as teachers, they were unable to understand God's truth. See how you translated "blind guides" in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:15:12|15:14]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

16.ref: by the temple, it is nothing
16.text: "by the temple does not have to keep his oath"

"is tied to his oath." Being required to do what one has said he would do in an oath is spoken of as if he is tied to the oath. AT: "must do what he promised to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

16.ref: Which is greater, the gold or the temple that makes the gold holy?
16.text: Jesus uses this question to rebuke the Pharisees because they treated the gold as if it were more important than the temple. AT: "The temple that has dedicated the gold to God is more important than the gold!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

16.ref: the temple that makes the gold holy
16.text: "the temple that makes the gold belong to God alone"

18.text: The understood information can be made clear. AT: "And you also say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
"he does not have to do what he has sworn to do" or "he does not have to keep his oath"
This is an animal or grain that a person would bring to God by putting it on God's altar.

"is tied to his oath." Being required to do what one has said he would do in an oath is spoken of as if he is tied to the oath. AT: "must do what he promised to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The Jewish leaders were spiritually blind. Although they thought of themselves as teachers, they were unable to understand God's truth. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

18.ref: Which is greater, the gift or the altar that makes the gift holy?
18.text: Jesus uses this question to rebuke the Pharisees for treating the gift as if it were more important than the altar. AT: "The altar that makes the gift holy is greater than the gift!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

18.ref: the altar that makes the gift holy
18.text: "the altar that makes the gift special to God"

20.text: "by all the gifts that people have placed on it"

20.ref: by him who lives in it ... by him who sits on it
20.text: Both of these refer to God the Father.

23.text: "How terrible it will be for you!" See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:11:20|11:21]].
These are various leaves and seeds people used to make food taste good. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])

23.ref: But these you ought to have done
23.text: "You ought to have obeyed these more important laws"

23.ref: and not to have left the other undone
23.text: This can be stated in positive form. AT: "while also obeying the less important laws" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])

Jesus uses this metaphor to describe the Pharisees. Jesus means that the Pharisees do not understand God's commands or how to please him. Therefore, they cannot teach others how to please God. See how you translated this metaphor in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:15:12|15:14]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

23.ref: you who strain out a gnat but swallow a camel
23.text: Being careful to follow the less important laws and ignoring the more important laws is as foolish as being careful not to swallow the smallest unclean animal but eating the meat of the largest unclean animal either purposely or unknowingly. AT: "you are as foolish as a person who strains out a gnat that falls into his drink but swallows a camel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
This means to pour a liquid through a cloth to remove a gnat from a drink.

25.text: "How terrible it will be for you!" See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:11:20|11:21]].

25.ref: For you clean the outside of the cup and of the plate, but inside they are full of greed and self-indulgence
25.text: indulgence** - This is a metaphor that means the scribes and Pharisees appear pure on the outside to others, but on the inside they are wicked. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

25.ref: they are full of greed and self-indulgence
25.text: indulgence** - "they want what others have, and they act in the interest of the self"
The Pharisees were spiritually blind. Although they thought of themselves as teachers, they were unable to understand God's truth. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

25.ref: Clean first the inside of the cup and of the plate, so that the outside may become clean also
25.text: This is a metaphor that means that if they would become pure in their inner being, then the result is that they would be pure on the outside as well. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

27.ref: you are like whitewashed tombs ... unclean
27.text: This is a simile that means the scribes and Pharisees may appear to be pure on the outside, but they are wicked on the inside. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

"tombs that someone has painted white." The Jews would paint tombs white so that people would easily see them and avoid touching them. Touching a tomb would make a person ceremonially unclean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

29.text: This nominal adjective can be stated as an adjective. AT: "of the righteous people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])

29.ref: in the days of our fathers
we would not have been participants with them
29.text: "we would not have joined with them"
Here "blood" refers to life. To shed blood means to kill. AT: "killing" or "murdering" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

32.ref: You also fill up the measure of your fathers
32.text: Jesus uses this as a metaphor meaning the Pharisees will complete the wicked behavior that their forefathers started when they killed the prophets. AT: "You also finish the sins your ancestors began" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

32.ref: You serpents, you offspring of vipers
32.text: Serpents and vipers are the same thing. They are dangerous and often symbols of evil. AT: "You are as evil as dangerous and poisonous snakes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "offspring" means "having the characteristic of." See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:03:07|3:7]].

32.ref: how will you escape the judgment of hell?
32.text: Jesus uses this question as a rebuke. AT: "there is no way for you to escape the judgment of hell!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

34.text: "I will send." Here "I" refers to Jesus.

34.ref: upon you will come all the righteous blood shed on the earth
34.text: The phrase "upon you will come" is an idiom that means to receive punishment. And, "blood" refers to a person's life. To shed blood means to kill. AT: "God will punish you for the murders of all the righteous people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

34.ref: from the blood ... to the blood
34.text: The word "blood" refers to a person's life. Here it means "bloodshed" or murder. AT: "from the murder ... to the murder" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Abel was the first victim of murder, and Zechariah was probably thought to be the last to be murdered, by Jews in the temple. These two men represent all the murdered righteous people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This Zechariah was not the father of John the Baptist.
Jesus does not mean the people to whom he is speaking actually killed Zechariah. He means their ancestors did.
"I tell you the truth." This adds emphasis to what Jesus says next.

37.text: Jesus mourns over the people of Jerusalem because they reject every messenger that God sends to them.
Jesus speaks to the people of Jerusalem as though they were the city itself. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_apostrophe]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

37.ref: those who are sent to you
37.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "those whom God sends to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Jesus is speaking to Jerusalem as if it is a woman and the people are her children. AT: "your people" or "your inhabitants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

37.ref: just as a hen gathers her chicks under her wings
37.text: This is a simile that emphasizes Jesus' love for the people and how he wanted to take care of them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
a female chicken. You can translate with any bird that protects her children under her wing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])

37.ref: your house is left to you desolate
37.text: "God will leave your house, and it will be empty"
Possible meanings are 1) "the city of Jerusalem" or 2) "the temple." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This adds emphasis to what Jesus says next.

37.ref: Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord
37.text: Here "in the name" means "in the power" or "as a representative." AT: "He who comes in the power of the Lord is blessed" or "He who comes as the representative of the Lord will be blessed." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:21:09|21:9]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
